vignette.presentation:
A 73-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of severe shortness of breath. The patient says, "It feels like I'm
suffocating." He has hypertension, coronary artery disease, and hypercholesterolemia. His medications are aspirin, clopidogre l, atorvastatin, and metoprolol.
On arrival, he is in severe respiratory distress and uses accessory muscles of respiration. He is only able to speak in short sentences. His temperature is
37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 123/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 245/113 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 15 L/min of oxygen by nonrebreather face
mask shows an oxygen saturation of 85%. Auscultation of the lungs discloses crackles to the apex bilaterally. Heart sounds are normal. Trace periphera l
edema is noted. An ECG is shown. The most appropriate next step is administration of which of the following?

question_stem: The most appropriate next step is administration of which of the following?

vignette.presentation:
A 57-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of nasal congestion and sneezing, a 5-hour history of fever, shaking chills,
and cough, and a 2-hour history of right-sided pleuritic chest pain. Sixteen months ago, he was diagnosed with multiple myeloma. His only medication is
prednisone for hypercalcemia. He is in obvious respiratory distress . His temperature is 40.2°C (104.4 °F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood
pressure is 110/65 mm Hg. There is dullness to percussion at both lung bases, increased tactile fremitus, and bronchial breathing. Tenderness is noted over
the left mid humerus. His hematocrit is 30%, and leukocyte count is 24,000/mim3 (24 x 109/L). An x-ray of the chest is consistent with bilateral lower lobe
pneumonia. A Gram stain of the sputum shows many segmented neutrophils, a few bronchial epithelial cells, and a moderate number of extracel lular gram
positive diplococci. This patient most likely has which of the following types of pneumonia?

vignette.presentation:
A 73-year-old woman who resides in a skilled nursing care facility is brought to the emergency department after she was found lethargic and minimally
responsive 30 minutes ago. She has had a 3-day history of vomiting and has not produced urine during the past 24 hours. She was hospitalized for
pneumonia 3 weeks ago. She has renal insufficiency, type 2 diabetes mellitus, congestive heart failure, and dementia. Her medications are furosemide,
metformin, and memantine. She has no known allergies. On arrival, the patient moans incoherently to questions or stimulation. Her temperature is 35.4 °C
(95. 7°F), pulse is 82/min and regular, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 90/43 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of
93%. The skin is cool and clammy to touch. Crackles are heard at the lung bases. The abdomen is soft; there is mild, diffuse tenderness to palpation. There is
moderate pitting edema of the lower extremities. She is able to move all four extremities, but she does not cooperate with a neurologic examination.
Fingerstick blood glucose concentrat ion is 78 mg/dl (4.33 mmol/L). An ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

vignette.presentation:
A 48-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of
severe left upper back pain. The pain began suddenly while he was golfing; he thought he may
have pulled a muscle during his swing but is surprised by the degree of pain. He rates the pain
as a 10 on a 10-point scale. It does not vary with deep breaths, exertion, movements of his
arms, or rotation of his trunk. He is concerned that he might be having a heart attack because
his 52-year-old brother just had a myocardial infarction. The patient has hypertension treated
with hydrochlorothiazide. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 29 years. On arrival,
the patient is diaphoretic and in moderate distress. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is
110/min and regular, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 180/90 mm Hg. Pulse
oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Jugular venous distention is noted.
Auscultation of the lungs discloses bilateral crackles. Cardiac examination discloses a diastolic
low-pitched murmur best heard at the upper right sternal border. Abdominal examination shows
no abnormalities. There is no peripheral edema. A chest x-ray and ECG are shown. Which of the
following is the most appropriate next step in management?
O
A) Administration of aspirin, nitroglycerin, and morphine

A 62-year-old man with chronic low back pain comes to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of feeling light-headed. He has not had chest
pain or palpitations. He says that he usually has constipation , but he has had bowel movements daily for the past 5 days. The stools are a dark reddish brown.
His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 140/min and regular, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. The patient is too light-headed to
check orthostatics. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The abdomen is soft, nontender, and not distended. Rectal examination shows soft, dark red stool; test
of the stool for occult blood is positive. Fingerstick blood glucose concentrat ion is 92 mg/dL (5.11 mmol/L). Laboratory studies show:

Hematocrit 22%

Serum
Lactate 6 mg/dL (0.67 mmol/L) [N 5-15 mg/dL//0.55-1.65 mmol/L]
Coagulation studies are within normal limits. An ECG shows no abnorma lities other than sinus tachycardia. A blood sample is sent for typing and crossmatch
laboratory studies. A subclav ian catheter is inserted, and its position is confirmed by chest x-ray. After administration of 0.9% saline (2 L) through a large-bore
peripheral intravenous catheter, pulse is 120/min and regular, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. Repeat serum lactate concentration is 4.5 mg/dL (0.5
mmol/L). Central venous pressure is 11 mm Hg (N 3-8). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

levels throughout; no air is noted in the rectum. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

vignette.presentation:
A 38-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband after she had a syncopal episode at home 30 minutes ago. On arrival, the
patient is doubled over in pain. She says that she had abdominal pain about an hour before she fainted, and that it has been continuous for the past
30 minutes. She says that she has never been pregnant, has been healthy, and is not taking any medicat ions. Her temperatu re is 37.3°C (99.2°F), pulse is
120/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropr iate first step?

vignette.presentation:
A 44-year-old woman comes to the emergency department 2 hours after the sudden onset of epigastr ic pain. The patient says the pain radiates to her back
and improves when she leans forward . She rates the pain as a 9 on 10-point scale. She has vomited twice and still feels nauseated . She has obesity and
cholelithiasis. She does not take any medications and has no known allergies. She drinks two glasses of wine on the weekends and does not smoke
cigarettes or use illicit drugs. BMI is 29 kg/m2. She appears uncomfortab le. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.2°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 18/min, and
blood pressure is 138/87 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturat ion of 98%. Physical exam ination discloses tenderness to palpation of
the epigastrium. The remainder of the examination discloses no abnorma lities. Laboratory studies show:
Leukocyte count 14,000/mm3 (14 x 109/L)
Serum
ALT 184 U/L
AST 126 U/L
Alkaline phosphatase 210 U/L
Lipase 368 U/L (N=14-280)
Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy at this time?

A 57-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his son 30 minutes after he had a tonic-clon ic seizure that lasted 1 minute. The patient is
disheveled and has difficulty giving a coherent h istory. The son reports that his father has a 20-year history of alcoholism and typically consumed 16 to 32 oz
(0.5 to 1 L) of vodka daily. The patient's temperatu re is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 150/70 mm Hg. The
skin is slightly jaundiced, and there are spider angiomas over the chest. Abdominal examination shows ascites. The liver edge is palpated 5 cm below the
right costal margin. Neurologic examinat ion shows a diffuse symmetr ical tremor. No asterixis is noted. His Mini-Mental State Examination score cannot be
quantified because he does not cooperate. In addition to intravenous fluids, multivitamins, folic acid, and vitamin B (thiamine), administration of which of the

47. A 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency departme nt 30 minutes after a syncopal episode. The patient experienced palpitations, weakness, and
dizziness, and then collapsed and lost consciousness for approximately 1 minute. He reports a similar episode 1 week ago for which he did not seek care.
The patient has congestive heart failure and hypertension treated with furosem ide and atenolol. On arrival, his temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min,
respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Auscultation of the chest
discloses clear lungs and no murmurs. During the examination he experiences another episode of palpitations. A rhythm strip is shown. The episode passes
and he reports feeling "normal" after resolution of the palpitations. Vital signs and physical examination remain unchanged after the episode. Administration
of which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
